data.title: Default diffuse BRDF should be Burley's
data.body: I think, assuming that we want who use Blender, Substance Painter etc. to get a familiar look by default using spatial material.

data.title: Moved mono module here
data.body:
The [GodotSharp](https://github.com/neikeq/GodotSharp) repository will be abandoned and the development will continue here. I'll check all the issues open there and move here those that are still valid (we will need a mono label).

Building steps: https://github.com/neikeq/GodotSharp/wiki/Building
Demos will be added [to this repository](https://github.com/neikeq/GodotSharpDemos). Right now, the only demo in there is outdated and won't work.
There is also [this old document](https://github.com/neikeq/GodotSharp/wiki/API-Differences) that lists some of the differences with GDScript. It's very old and it will be updated once I finish re-witing/updating the bindings of the built-in types.

In general, many things will need to be documented. Please, review (alpha2 is around the corner), comment any doubt you could have and give feedback (specially related to Godot coding standards I may have broken).

I must note that there were [a few contributors](https://github.com/neikeq/GodotSharp/graphs/contributors), but it's not possible to use the commits from that repository (let me know If you know a way) and it was squashed into a single commit.

Travis will be failing for now, it's normal.

data.title: 2D viewport texture wrong color space when rendered in 3D
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Godot 3.0 master https://github.com/godotengine/godot/commit/0c82d113edc4f7cc1bef11c2e03b2a1b39de90fb

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
The 2D in 3D demo looks like this:
![https://i.imgur.com/MOjWjDj.png](https://i.imgur.com/MOjWjDj.png)
But the 2D part of that demo looks like this:
![https://i.imgur.com/01OtNMz.png](https://i.imgur.com/01OtNMz.png)

It looks like the viewport texture's color space needs to be converted. I tested this theory by converting the `SpatialMaterial` from the `viewport_quad` to a `ShaderMaterial` and adding [this conversion ](https://github.com/glslify/glsl-gamma/blob/master/in.glsl#L11-L13) to the albedo like:

```glsl
...
	ALBEDO = albedo.rgb * albedo_tex.rgb;
	ALBEDO = pow(ALBEDO, vec3(2.2)); // toLinear
...
```
Which gave me this result:
![https://i.imgur.com/mefeeFw.png](https://i.imgur.com/mefeeFw.png)
![https://i.imgur.com/BMsq5Gh.png](https://i.imgur.com/BMsq5Gh.png)
Camera as close as possible to only show the 2D part.

And this seems pretty close and good enough for the 98% of the uses for this (when talking about 2D on 3D) But you kinda have to know how to fix it and most people won't know.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Open the 2d_in_3d demo
2. Run it

**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->
https://github.com/godotengine/godot-demo-projects/tree/master/viewport/2d_in_3d

data.title: Visual Scripting - scroll axis is flipped in script canvas
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
OS: Mac OS 10.12.6  Godot 3.0master build 42e2821

Scroll wheel moves the canvas left/right, Shift+scroll wheel moves the canvas up/down.  This is the opposite of "standard" scroll behavior in other programs.

data.title: Visual Scripting - no PackedScene var type
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
3.0master build 42e2821

I would like to add a `PackedScene` var for instancing as we do in GDScript:

    export (PackedScene) var Mob

but `PackedScene` does not appear in "Edit Variable" -> "Type" list.

data.title: Allow fine tuning of collision constraints
data.body:
Allow to set a default priority and bias for collision resolution. Also allow to override these values for a given collision shape.

The values used in the body pair are computed as the max value of the values of the two participating shapes (or the default ones)

Also expose some physics body state values such as center of mass, principal inertia axes and inertia vector/inertia tensor at the physics body level

data.title: [DOCS] Adds JSON and JSONParseResult doc
data.body: I saw that GDScript.parse_json and GDScript.to_json is still here, JSON class is not here to replace that

data.title: Fix environmental BRDF.
Tooltip misplacement when using Camera2D and zooming
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Win7, Godot 2.1.4 stable

**Issue description:**
When using a zoomed Camera2D, it seems that tooltips will be zoomed and their position is wrong, instead of following the cursor it is spawned way off (maybe it uses the transformed mouse position instead), it should use the global mouse position, it doesn't make sense for viewport transformation to be applied on tooltips


**Steps to reproduce:**
Add a Camera2D, change the zoom variable, add a control with a tooltip, when you run it and hover over the control the tool tip will show up in a different position (may be offscreen)

data.title: Can't use anisotropic filtering
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Windows 7 64-bit
Godot 3.0 alpha 1
AMD Radeon HD 7660D + HD 6670 Dual Graphics

**Issue description:**
I wanted to use anisotropic filtering for textures, because I have a really large plane in the scene, but I got this instead:
![Image](https://imgur.com/download/jpBBX0p)

And the console output says:
![Image](https://imgur.com/download/QwB1FMd)

The **Project Settings** seems to have a `filters/anisotropic_filter_level` but apparently makes no difference. I also tried to manually create a `rendering/quality/anisotropic_filter_level` but to no effect.

I know it's not my drivers because I can use anisotropic filtering when coding directly in C++ with OpenGL.

**Steps to reproduce:**
The scene layout is:
```
- Node
  - MeshInstance (with a Plane Mesh)
  - Camera
```

I then created a material for the MeshInstance with an albedo texture. The texture has `Anisotropic` and all others flag checked.

**Link to minimal example project:**
[godot3-blastoide.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1346767/godot3-blastoide.zip)

data.title: Change to Image::shrink_x2 function preventing it set a 0 width/height for mipmapped textures
data.body:
- Fixes importing of small resolution PNG.
For example we have a PNG file with 30 width x 59 height, ResourceImporterTexture::_save_stex shrinks it 7 times because of int this line "mmc = image->get_mipmap_count() + 1;", so libpng fails because near the last iteration it adds a 0 width mipmap.
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/359440300059394051/363148353527349248/unknown.png

data.title: Shader Param textures are null after converting SpatialMaterial to ShaderMaterial
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Godot 3.0 master (2c5fa0947d724c0dcb24643f692f7a9d686a5490)

**Issue description:**
When you convert a SpatialMaterial with textures to a ShaderMaterial, the Shader Param section of the inspector shows that the textures are null even though the textures are applied to the shader.

**Steps to reproduce:**
- Create a mesh
- Add a SpatialMaterial
- Add an albedo texture
- Convert the SpatialMaterial to ShaderMaterial

![screenshot-20170930-11 13 21](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1168026/31048406-4ef1e2b8-a5d1-11e7-96f5-2ca0d178bbc3.png)

Might be related to https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/11429

data.title: Nodes which blend mode set to Add will show through semitransparent editor layers
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Godot 3.0 master https://github.com/godotengine/godot/commit/42e2821d04a5efd434fffa090e817905d30a0c73

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
![https://i.imgur.com/YzeFlTR.gifv](https://i.imgur.com/YzeFlTR.gif)
![https://i.imgur.com/tg3C5nB.gifv](https://i.imgur.com/tg3C5nB.gif)

Both particles and the red sprite have their blend mode set to Add.

I don't think this is a must fix issue because that's the expected behavior of the add blend mode. The only way I can think of to fix this would be to render the preview viewport to a texture first but I'm not sure if this should be done because 99.98% of the time this issue won't be a problem. I'm still opening it to discuss if it'll be fixed and what can be done.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Add a sprite
2. Set the blend mode to Add
3. Open a window and move it so the sprite can be seen

data.title: Feature Request: WYSIWYG composition for viewport textures (3D in Godot 3.0)
data.body:
Check the GUI_In_3D demo on how, right now at least, you need to compose the viewport texture blind (you get the 2D window when you add a UI node, but nothing shows up).

So it would be nice to be able to see the composition you are making, as I imagine the current situation will prove to be a headache for very complex stuff.

Can this be done, would it be good to have?

data.title: Update VS project generation
data.body: Update VS project generation and add num_jobs option (default value: 2 - the same as before) for parallel builds inside Visual Studio. Tested with SCons 3.0 and Visual Studio 2017. Fixes problem with SCons current directory (now set to $(ProjectDir)), when running build in VS.

data.title: [DOCS] Write member, signals and constants in the Control class
data.body:
**Need your feedback**:

1. There's similar text on multiple entries (e.g. values for enums). We discussed this with @cbscribe and concluded it's necessary as people can browse entries in any order, and each should have a proper description. Also, the reader will see the pattern easily. But as enums are boken down into individual constants, it can make for a lot of text.
2. I left the following properties and constants out:

   * rect_clip_content, I think it should let me resize the node below the content's size, but even with the minimum size set to (0,0) Godot won't let me
   * mouse_filter, grow_horizontal and grow_vertical, same issue, after testing I don't know when they're necessary, so can't document them.
   * GROW_DIRECTION_BEGIN, GROW_DIRECTION_END, MOUSE_FILTER_STOP, MOUSE_FILTER_PASS, MOUSE_FILTER_IGNORE, constants that correspond to the member variables above

For the mouse_filter, I couldn't see what it does in 3.0 alpha 1. For the grow_direction, I can see they might change the size calculation when the node's size changes, but in practice, with containers, I couldn't see a difference. If you know when to use it, please tell me and I'll add them to the PR.

data.title: Feature Request: Anchor drop down updates margins
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Godot 2.1.4

**Issue description:**
Changing a node's anchor settings via the dropdown does not move the node.  This seems counter-intuitive and unsatisfying.  For example, selecting "full rect" should expand the node (setting all margins to 0) to fill its parent.

data.title: GridMap - Include transforms of tile object's children when generating .meshlib file
data.body:
_(currently using Godot 3.0, build from the 27th of September)_

When creating a meshlib for use with a GridMap, the engine currently forces all components of each tile to be centred. This makes sense for neatly rotatable tiles of uniform size. But in some use cases, you want objects that are off-centre, and you still want them to have collision details.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1318345/31046141-f064dd3e-a636-11e7-9453-9f3854774f0d.png)
- My bookshelf model is deliberately off-centre so that it can be placed against a wall (it only takes up half a grid-space along one axis)
- If I want to add a StaticBody with a BoxCollisionShape, I can't offset them to cover just the geometry (because they don't export their transforms, they are locked to the centre of the tile, or grid space)
- I can centre its pivot in my modelling program, then I can apply the StaticBody and BoxCollisionShape. This will give me correct collision geometry, but my object is then forced to be in the centre of the tile/grid-space (which is undesired).
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1318345/31046153-20d1a8f8-a637-11e7-9efb-709edb698490.png)
- Ideally, the children of the MeshInstance nodes should retain their transforms when a .meshlib is created from a scene.

This effect is exaggerated if you imagine the bookshelf is a painting, or something thin that you would typically mount on a wall, not in the centre of a grid space.

You can also imagine a half-tile object in a grid space would be affected by this issue.

data.title: Fixes some retina problems on multi monitor setups
data.body:
This is a small OS X retina display code overhaul to fix several problems with wrong hidpi scaling on setups on OS X involving multiple monitors, when some of them retina and some of them are non-retina.

With the current code, scaling basically only works if you start on the retina screen if it also has the menu bar.

With this PR, what works now in a setup with one retina and one non-retina screen, is:

- starting on the retina screen, if the retina screen has the menu bar
- starting on the retina screen, if the non-retina screen has the menu bar
- starting on the non-retina screen, if the retina screen has the menu bar
- starting on the non-retina screen, if the non-retina screen has the menu bar

The PR also changes two cross-platform assumptions in `EditorNode` and `ProjectManager` that are currently hard coded to the dpi of screen `0`, which was one cause of the problems and which seems plain wrong to me on all platforms.

data.title: looking_at and look_at in 3D does not rotate around only to the up-vector.
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Windows 7 64-bit
Godot 3.0 master-build

**Issue description:**
looking_at is a method in Transform and look_at a method in any Spatial node. 
By using up vector Vector3(0,1,0) to make the rotation around the y-axis the result is to rotate the object and in x - axis.
What was expected was to use only the y axis (the up vector)

**Steps to reproduce:**
Create a camera and move it up or down and away from the origin of the world.
Create a script in the camera and put in the _ready method this line:
`transform = transform.looking_at(Vector3(), Vector3(0,1,0))`
or this
`look_at(Vector3(), Vector3(0,1,0))`

When you run it you can see that the camera was rotated in two different axis. 
e.g. y and x

**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->
[lookin_at.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1346271/lookin_at.zip).

data.title: Merged iphone and osx audio drivers into drivers/coreaudio

data.title: Add script dialogue class name (probably?) shouldn't get disabled
data.body: In the add script dialogue, selecting a script file disables Class Name input box, but it's contents are apparently important because when the class name if empty, you get "Invalid Class Name" in red below.

data.title: Access to normal buffer in shading language
data.body: Currently shading language allows access to screen space depth texture. It'd be nice if we had access to the normal buffer as well.
